Controller¶

Documentation¶

class pyroborobo.Controller¶

Class to extend a Roborobo Controller in python.

Warning

If the __init__ is overridden, it is absolutely necessary to call the PyController constructor by doing :

def __init__(self, world_model):
    PyController.__init__(self, world_model)

Not doing so leads to cryptic errors due to the interface between python and c++.

It is also necessary to override step and reset. Not doing so leads to cryptic errors.

property absolute_orientation¶

Absolute orientation of the robot

Type

Float

property absolute_position¶

Robot’s absolute position

Type

Tuple[int, int]

get_all_distances(self: pyroborobo.Controller) → List[float]¶

Return a numpy array of all distances.

get_distance_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → float¶

float: The distance to the object in range [0, 1], if 1, nothing is in sight

get_ground_sensor_values(self: pyroborobo.Controller) → tuple¶

tuple[float, float, float]: (red, green, blue) from the ground sensor of the robot between [0,1]

get_object_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → int¶

Bool: Tell if it’s a physical object seen by the sensor sensor_id

get_object_instance_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → PhysicalObject¶
get_robot_controller_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → pyroborobo.Controller¶

Controller: Get the robot’s controller seen by the sensor sensor_id

get_robot_id_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → int¶

Robot: Get the robot instance seen by the sensor sensor_id

get_robot_relative_orientation_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → float¶

float: Get robot’s relative orientation compared to self seen by the sensor sensor_id

get_wall_at(self: pyroborobo.Controller, sensor_id: int) → int¶

Bool: Tell if it’s a wall seen by the sensor sensor_id

property id¶

Robot unique ID.

Type

int

property nb_sensors¶

Number of sensors of the robot

Type

int

reset(self: pyroborobo.Controller) → None¶

call at the initialisation of roborobo

property rotation¶

the robot’s actual rotation speed between [-1, 1]

Type

float

set_color(self: pyroborobo.Controller, arg0: int, arg1: int, arg2: int) → None¶

Set the color of the robot (r,g,b). :param: r int [0, 255] :param: g int [0, 255] :param: b int [0, 255]

set_rotation(self: pyroborobo.Controller, rotation_speed: float) → None¶

Set the robot rotation speed between [-1, 1]

set_translation(self: pyroborobo.Controller, trans_speed: float) → None¶

Set the robot translation speed between [-1, 1]

step(self: pyroborobo.Controller) → None¶

Takes the decision of the robot’s next action

You can access the sensors and effectors of the robot by reading and modifying its world_model.

Called at each time step of the simulation.

Examples

>>> def step(self):
...     distance = self.world_model.camera_pixel_distance
...     if np.all(distance < 0.5):
...         # Nothing around, we can go forward without turning
...         self.world_model.translation = 2
...         self.world_model.rotation = 0
...     else:
...         # There are obstacles, we go around in circles slowly
...         self.world_model.translation = 0.5
...         self.world_model.rotation = 15
property translation¶

the robot’s actual translation speed between [-1, 1]

Type

float

property world_model¶

The robot’s world_model

Type

pyroborobo.WorldModel

Template¶

If you want to create a subclass of a controller, you can use this template:

class MyController(Controller):
    def __init__(self, wm):
        super().__init__(wm)
        self.rob = Pyroborobo.get()

    def reset(self):
        super().reset()

    def step(self):
        super().step()
